title: 113_s849
content: The Act is titled the "Permanent Stewardship Contracting Authority Act of 2013" and amends the Healthy Forests Restoration Act of 2003 to include stewardship end result contracting projects. The Chief and Director can enter into stewardship contracting projects with private or public entities to achieve land management goals for national forests and public lands. Goals may include road maintenance, habitat restoration, and prescribed fires. The Chief and Director can enter into stewardship contracting projects with private or public entities for various land management goals, such as prescribed fires, vegetation removal, watershed restoration, wildlife maintenance, and weed control. Agreements or contracts for these projects are selected based on best value, considering sources from other agreements or contracts. The Chief and Director can enter into contracts for the sale of property under specific terms set by the Secretary of Agriculture. The contract term can exceed 5 years but not exceed 10 years, and the value of timber or forest products can be used as offsets. The value of timber or forest products can be used as an offset against the cost of services received under the contract, determined using appropriate appraisal methods. The Chief and the Director may collect monies from an agreement or contract under subsection (b) if the collection is a secondary objective that will best achieve the purposes of this section. Monies collected can be used as an offset against the cost of services received under the contract, determined using appropriate appraisal methods. Monies collected from agreements or contracts under subsection (b) can be retained by the Chief and Director for expenditure at the project site where collected or another site. The value of services received and payments made under stewardship contracts are not considered National Forest System or public lands monies. The Knutson-Vanderberg Act does not apply to agreements or contracts under subsection (b). The Chief may collect deposits from a contractor for the costs of removing timber or forest products. Performance and payment bonds may be required by the Chief and Director under the Federal Acquisition Regulation. The contracting officer may require sufficient protection for the government's investment in receipts generated by the contractor from forest products. If the forest products' value exceeds resource improvement costs, residual receipts can be collected under the Knutson-Vanderberg Act and applied to other stewardship projects. The Chief and Director must establish a monitoring and evaluation process. The Chief and Director must establish a multiparty monitoring and evaluation process for stewardship contracting projects. Participants may include cooperating governmental agencies, tribal governments, and other interested groups. They are required to report annually to the Senate and House Committees on Agriculture on the status of agreements or contracts under subsection (b). The Chief and Director must establish a multiparty monitoring and evaluation process for stewardship contracting projects, including reporting on specific accomplishments and the role of local communities. Section 347 of the Department of the Interior and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1999 is repealed.
